author: Daphne
label: NO
scenario: Patients with symptom B prescribed Drug A have higher hospitalization rates that patients with symptom B not prescribed Drug A.
key_insight: Confounding by indication is a type of bias in observational studies where the medical reason (indication) for prescribing a treatment also independently affects the health outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Were the symptoms the reason for hospitalization or drug?
conditional_answers: If the symptoms were the reason for the hospitalization and the reason for the drug prescription, then the drug did not necessarily cause the hospitalization.
wise_refusal: The symptom is a confounder that could cause both hospitalization and drug prescription, so it is not necessarily the case that Drug A causes hospitalization.
the_statistical_structure: The observed association reflects confounding by indication, because symptoms influence both treatment assignment and outcome.
correct_reasoning: Using randomized control trials to control for confounders is necessary to determine causation of drug effects. Associations cannot establish causality.

author: Daphne
label: NO
scenario: Cities with more electric‑vehicle charging stations appear to have lower asthma rates.
key_insight: Stricter environmental policies drive both cleaner air and more EV infrastructure.
hidden_timestamp: Were strong air‑quality regulations already in place before EV infrastructure expanded?
conditional_answers: If regulations preceded EV growth, the association is confounded; if EV stations were deployed independently of regulation, a causal link is more plausible.
wise_refusal: We cannot attribute lower asthma rates to EV stations without measuring regulatory differences.
the_statistical_structure: An omitted policy variable creates a spurious correlation between EV infrastructure and health outcomes.
correct_reasoning: Adjusting for regulatory strength is required before interpreting EV station density as causal.

author: Daphne
label: NO
scenario: Neighborhoods with more gyms have lower heart‑disease mortality.
key_insight: An unconsidered socioeconomic status variable could explain both the number of gyms and the heart disease mortality.
hidden_timestamp: Was socioeconomic status already high before the gyms were created?
conditional_answers: If socioeconomic status preceded gyms, the association is confounded; if gyms were randomly placed, the effect may be causal.
wise_refusal: We cannot infer causality without measuring SES.
the_statistical_structure: An unobserved common cause creates a spurious correlation between X and Y.
correct_reasoning: Adjusting for SES is required before interpreting gym density as causal.

author: Daphne
label: NO
scenario: Doctors compare patients who start Drug A to those who do not and conclude the drug halves heart attack risk
key_insight: High risk patients are more likely to be prescribed the drug and more likely to have events
hidden_timestamp: Z was measured before prescribing and high risk patients preferentially received Drug A
conditional_answers: If high risk patients were more likely to get Drug A then Z confounds the estimated effect; if prescribing was unrelated to Z then the estimate is less biased
wise_refusal: We cannot trust the apparent protective effect unless we show risk was balanced or adjusted
the_statistical_structure: An unblocked backdoor path Z to X and Z to Y biases the naive comparison of treated and untreated groups
correct_reasoning: We must adjust for baseline risk or use randomization to estimate the true effect of Drug A.

author: Daphne
label: NO
scenario: A study claims intensive insulin therapy reduces complications but sicker diabetics are escalated earlier to intensive regimens
key_insight: Disease severity drives both escalation to intensive therapy and later complications
hidden_timestamp: Z is recorded at multiple visits before each treatment change
conditional_answers: If rising severity precedes treatment escalation then Z confounds the effect; if treatment changes are unrelated to severity trajectories then the estimate is more valid
wise_refusal: We cannot attribute outcome differences to insulin intensity without modeling severity over time
the_statistical_structure: Time varying confounding arises because past Z affects both current treatment choice and future outcomes
correct_reasoning: We need methods like marginal structural models to properly adjust for time dependent severity.

author: Daphne
label: NO
scenario: Clinicians observe that patients enrolled in a new therapy program have lower relapse than those who decline and conclude the program is effective
key_insight: More motivated patients are both more likely to enroll and less likely to relapse
hidden_timestamp: Z is assessed during intake before the choice to enroll
conditional_answers: If more motivated patients preferentially enroll then the effect estimate is confounded; if motivation is similar in both groups then the estimate is less biased
wise_refusal: We should not credit the program alone when we have not accounted for motivation
the_statistical_structure: The backdoor path from Z to X and Z to Y inflates the apparent benefit of therapy
correct_reasoning: We must compare patients with similar motivation or adjust statistically before claiming causal benefit.

author: Daphne
label: NO
scenario: A registry comparison suggests patients who receive Hospital B s oncology protocol live longer than those on Hospital A protocol
variables, Z: Referral pattern and patient socioeconomic status
key_insight: Wealthier and healthier patients are more often referred to Hospital B and have better survival regardless of protocol
hidden_timestamp: Z is determined before referral decisions are made
conditional_answers: If well resourced patients are systematically sent to Hospital B then selection on Z confounds protocol comparisons; if referrals ignore Z then the difference is more credible
wise_refusal: We cannot attribute survival differences solely to the protocol without accounting for referral and SES
the_statistical_structure: An unblocked backdoor from Z to care site X and Z to survival Y creates a spurious treatment effect
correct_reasoning: We should risk adjust or use designs that balance referral patterns before comparing protocols.

label: NO

key_insight: Health conscious individuals are more likely to sign up and also to manage their weight

wise_refusal: We cannot infer the program works without adjusting for pre existing health behaviors
the_statistical_structure: The association between X and Y is biased by Z which influences both participation and outcome
correct_reasoning: We must control for baseline health consciousness to estimate the causal effect of the gym membership.
